intro: Mendoncella acuminata, commonly known as the sharp-pointed spurge, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and showy, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, wooded areas and has alternate, lance-shaped leaves. It produces small, greenish-yellow flowers that are clustered in cyathia, which are modified inflorescences typical of the spurge family. The plant is often found in wetlands and is adapted to thrive in humid, nutrient-rich soils.
